response.answer_text: tl;dr Apple products are and are not overpriced. Yes, Apple products are overpriced. Do you only want to run Windows? Or Android? Are you satisfied with slow hardware? Are you looking for the most raw processing power per dollar (that’s me)? Or, do you have a very tight computing budget? If you’ve answered yes to one or more of these questions there’s a good chance that Apple products are overpriced for you. No, Apple products are not overpriced and are worth it. Do you like using macOS or iOS? Do you prefer to have faster or premium hardware, typically with good build quality? Are you prepared to spend the money to buy a premium product? Do you need something that “just works”? Then, Apple products are definitely not overpriced. Usage scenario determines an Apple product’s worth. I’ve been a Mac user for over 30 years. In the past five years or so I’ve been exclusively a Windows or Linux user, not because I now dislike Macs or Mac OS X or macOS, but, because Windows 7 and 10 met and meet my current needs at a price-point that works for the cheapskate in me. Now, I’m even at a point where Windows meets my needs better than contemporary Macs do, at a (sometimes much) lower price point. You get what you pay for. What has stood out for me over the years is that the vast majority of Apple products prove the idiom, “you get what you pay for”. While Apple products typically fetch a premium, 9 times out of 10 they’re actually worth it. Virus and malware. For the vast majority of the Mac’s history (let’s say from 1984 to 2015, the year Windows 10 came out) Macs were virus and spyware free while the same could not be said for the Windows competition. Considering how much data has been lost over the years on Windows computers to viruses and malware that single fact has undoubtedly paid some Mac users dividends many times over. A single lost commercial project on a Windows computer would instantly swing the value proposition in Mac’s favour. Productivity. Macs and now iPhones were and are also simpler to maintain and have allowed their users to perform more complicated tasks with less training than DOS and then Windows computers and now Android devices (Android is distinctly messier, less consistent and less stable than its iOS counterpart). This too pays dividends. For instance, in the early 90’s it would’ve been impossible to do any form of graphics work or serious word processing (without major training) on DOS or Windows 2.x/3.x while Macs chugged along. Macs allowed normal people to earn a good living while DOS/Windows only afforded that luxury to highly trained individuals. Win for Apple product. Resale value. Try reselling the vast majority of Android devices or Windows computers. Unless the device belonged to a desirable and unique line, chances are your Android/Windows device has lost a huge chunk of its value. By contrast, Apple products retain their value—to the point where it’s nearly worth paying that little bit extra to buy a new device with warranty rather than a really old used device. Yes, you pay more up front, but, you can sell them for much more later. For example, I’ve been keeping my eye on a 2010-era Mac Mini to run as a headless Xamarin iOS compiler using Apple’s iOS IDE. A Mac Mini from 2010 sells for between 1/2 and 2/3 (~$300-~$500) of its 2010 price (~$600+) in late 2017. By contrast, you’d find it challenging to even give away a 7 year old $600 Windows desktop from 2010!

Updated Post: For Apple products from 2016 and earlier, I would say yes, they are worth the price (mainly because these are the ones I have the most experience with.) However, I will agree with the others that the iPhone X seems overpriced for what you get. After trying one in Target, I was a little bit underwhelmed by its performance. I was however, quite impressed with the new iPad Pro X performance, and I like that they switched to the more universal USB-C instead of the proprietary Lightning port. BUT… I am concerned about durability after seeing this bend test on Youtube. (Bend happens at 6:28 timestamp.)  Beside my current Apple products, I now also own an Eluktronics P650HP6 gaming laptop, and a Huawei P10+ Android smartphone (was a gift). So far I have been quite happy with the P650HP6 laptop, which currently has no hardware issues since getting it new on Mar. 2017. It has some of the best hardware I have seen at that price ($1300, Intel i7–7700HQ 2.8 GHz., 16 GB RAM, 256GB SSD + 1TB hard-drive, Nvidia GeForce GTX 1060 6GB VRAM). I got it to render 3D projects in Blender, and run graphically intensive games for use in machinima. Windows 10 can be a pain in the neck sometimes, especially because of the automatic updates, but I found a way to shut that off. I have noticed more minor glitches and hiccups compared to Mac's OS X. Overall, I would gladly purchase this laptop over any of the flagships offered by Dell, Asus, or Lenovo. I might consider HP, but so far Eluktronics is my go-to for pre-built Windows-based machines. I still use my BootCamped iMac for family gaming and occasional workflow. I am hot and cold about the Huawei P10+. I love the camera for photos, (but am disappointed in the video quality, which lacks in indoor conditions when compared to my sister's iPhone 6S Plus or my iPad Pro.). I do appreciate the higher versatility of the Android platform (when compared to iOS). However, I am not impressed with the occasional lags its gets, especially when the P10+ supposedly has an octa-core CPU, Kirin 960 chipset, and 6GB of RAM. (Also supposedly it has a high-end GPU.) I have found, app optimization for this specific smartphone is poor. I play a 3D mobile game called Noblemen that runs at 60 FPS and medium-high graphics settings on my iPad Pro (2016 model), but the P10+ struggles even at 30 FPS at medium settings. Also, Stopmotion Studio unfortunately performs poorly on the P10+, which gives me muxer errors when I try to render or export the videos (the same app runs flawlessly on my iPad). Another issue I have with the P10+ is the battery life. Even with battery optimizing apps, there is a slew of background processes that drain it's battery with a few days, even if it's not being used by me. I am considering getting the somewhat old Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge, which would probably have much better optimization than the Huawei P10+, due to the S7 Edge being a more well known device. On another comparison (headphones): I have several 3.5 mm AUX jack versions of the Apple Earpod. For $13 new and OEM from Ebay, the sound quality has a bit more depth and color than my SkullCandy Ink'd wireless earbuds (However, this may change after I use the Ink'd earbuds more and "burn them in" a bit. I got the Ink'd earbuds for $35 on sale at my local Target, but they are usually $50). Additionally, the Earpods even rival the clarity of my mom's $150 Bose Soundlink On-Ear headphones. Surprisingly, it was Target's $20 HeyDay brand wireless earbuds that had almost the same sound quality as my Earpods (however, I returned them due to the unreliable battery life.) Dec. 24, 2018, Changes since original post: My iPad 3's battery recently went caput after lending it to my mom for movie watching, and we neglected to charge it. Its battery went below 20% for too long. I usually try to maintain 40% to 80% battery capacity on my devices before storing for periods longer than 1 month, but unfortunately as they say, "out of sight, out of mind." My sister has upgraded from her 5C to an 6S Plus (bought used) that she utilizes as her daily "computer"… drawing art, watching videos, reading articles and such. My mom upgraded from her 5C to a 6S. I use her 5C now, since I only need it for calls, and use my iPad Pro as my main device. I recommended to 6S series to them due to the balance of price, performance, and usable longevity (the 64-bit architecture should allow them to upgrade to iOS 13 and most likely a few more later iterations.) Original Post: (Note: some points in the original are now outdated. Refer to above for updated info.) Short answer: No, Apple products are not unnecessarily expensive. Long Answer: I live in Hawaii where the humidity is nearly 100%. Humidity + Electronics = No good. I own the following: iPad Pro 9.7″ (aka: iPad 7), iPad 3, iPod Touch 5, iPad 1, iPhone 4, 2013 iMac 27″, and a 2012 Macbook Pro 15″. I love them. All my machines are currently fully functional except for the 2012 Macbook Pro (It's logic board is about to give out. It's lasted 5 years without repairs, so far. I bought it new.). My sister owns the following: iPhone 5C, iPhone 4S, and a 2013 Macbook 13″. Her iPhone 4S' speakers and volume buttons are shot, but the rest of the phone still works. (Lasted 5 years so far. We bought it new.) Her iPhone 5C screen is beginning to loosen, but otherwise it functions properly. (Lasted 2 years, so far. Seller refurbished. My fault.) Her Macbook Pro is running swell for more than a year, so far. (Bought new.) My mom owns the following: iPhone 5C, iPod Touch 1, 2010 iMac 21.5", 2008 Macbook Pro 15″, 2008 Macbook 13″, and a 2005 eMac. All her mobile devices are still fully functional. Her Macbooks conked out back in 2012 (they lasted about 4 to 5 years. Bought them new). Her 2010 iMac had a hard-drive failure, but a friend got it replaced for us and now the iMac is back in business (ran a total of 6 to 7 years before the harddrive failure. We bought it used.). Heck, I'm pretty sure if I pulled her old eMac out, it would still boot today. Probably the other biggest selling point on Apple products for me is their customer support. Unfortunately, I have noticed that recently their support has not been as stellar. But is is still significantly better than say the customer support of Dell, Asus, or HP, in my humble observations. I have been doing a lot of research on high-end laptops from HP, Lenovo, Dell, etc. I noticed that a lot of their products (even their top-line models) are receiving a lot of negative reviews. Look up reviews on the Dell Inspiron, HP Spectre, Asus Zenbook & ROG, and Lenovo Thinkpad high-end product lines, while you're on Amazon. Many of their negative reviews talk about recurring issues and provide substantial details on what went wrong with their machines (sometimes within weeks or months of receiving them). As mentioned above, I noticed a lot of people were having bad experiences with their customer support as well. I decided to look up reviews for the new Macbook Pro on Amazon just now, and I noticed it has a much higher percentage of substantial positive reviews. Of course, there was also a number of negative reviews that mentioned an unsatisfactory battery life and other issues, but I noticed many of these negative reviews were less detailed and less substantial (i.e. they didn’t mention what they were running on their computer when they got a short battery life.) compared to the critical reviews provided by customers who had issues with their Dell, Asus, HP, Acer, and Lenovo computers. Sure, Apple products may not have the most impressive specs on paper. However, their machines (especially their mobile devices) have lasted our family a friggin' long time! To me, the specs on rivals' PCs (or even Android devices for that matter) don't mean much to me, if the machine will fail in such a short amount of time. And what’s more is: why would I buy a computer if the company won’t even stand behind their product? (Look at the Dell reviews especially.) I know this sounds strange, but this really is a place where the saying "you get what you pay for" is actually wrong in some cases. Take for example the high-end Asus Zenbooks which are over $2000. For the price, you would expect a high quality machine, yet there are many Amazon reviews pointing out major screen and longevity issues. You can get a Macbook Pro 15.4in. for around the same price, which has more consistent quality and performance. If you have a computer guru friend who can repair computers for you, then brand is less of a concern. It really then comes down to your budget, computer needs (i.e. gaming, graphics work, music production, etc.), how long you want the machines to last, and if customer service is an important aspect to you. Cheers!

Ok, so this is quite a tough one as from my perspective there are a few reasons that anyone could tell you and a few that most people overlook. Because they make quality devices: Apple has a history of pricey products and they get away with it because of brand loyalty. However simply stating “brand loyalty” is a weak point as the company must have done something to earn such a thing. The products Apple make are usually extremely well made, top of the line and very premium in the build. Whatever people may say a good looking device will sell better than a similar competitor in specs if the said competitor is less attractive. iDevices have that bespoke look to them that I don’t think any other ecosystem has been able to replicate yet. You could take a glance at a closed Macbook and tell it’s an Apple product without even seeing the logo on top. So yes, in a way the first point is that Apple can price their products higher than similar competitors because they are the best-designed devices on the planet. Some could argue but there hasn’t been a single iPhone that for its time look bad or felt cheap. Apple always prioritises quality. A trait many people flock to. Because they’re Apple! : I personally don’t agree with this one but many people will simply state that the buyers are so indoctrinated by now that the iOS and MacOS users simply cannot switch away from their iPhones or Macs etc. And while yes I would agree many find it hard to leave the Apple bubble this isn’t because the user gets withdrawal from not having an apple logo on their device it’s for many other reasons which I hope to cover below. Apple’s Operating Systems: Need I say more? If I purely focus on iOS for the minute (as this is the OS I know more about vs MacOS) I can conclude that it is a masterpiece of software engineering and one of the best mobile OS’s ever devised. It boasts features that many people find indispensable and thus switching away is much harder. Using iMessage as an example many users would feel lost without it! It’s such a natural thing to many iPhone users that when they are presented with an Android device they forget that they can’t just send pictures easily anymore or they can’t send files and attachments without using a secondary app such as WhatsApp or FB Messenger. I could go on and on listing feature after feature but you get the idea. iOS, and MacOS by extension, just work and for many casual users who aren’t interested in customisation or tweaking their device, this is a dream come true. When Apple released the first iPhone it was a breath of fresh air in a world dominated by clunky, complex and slow mobile devices. Hell, have you seen Android 1.0? THIS is what built that famous Apple Sheep culture. Not the fact that they were born and instantly wanted an iPhone but because Apple earned that trust. People are willing to spend more money if they feel safe in the purchase. iPhones as far back as the 5s are STILL getting updates 5 years down the line. It comforts buyers that their purchase is going to be supported. Meanwhile, if you bought a Galaxy S8 only 1 year ago chances are you may see Android P sometime next year and then that’s it! 2 years of slow, patchy support then nothing. The Hardware-Software Issue: This is a point I feel not many people tend to make but I feel it is the most important factor at play here. Samsung as a company make smartphones and other devices. OnePlus makes smartphones and other devices. Dell makes laptops and desktop PCs. You know what all of these companies have in common that Apple does not? Samsung and OnePlus make the hardware for their devices. They design the body, the framework and how everything is going to come together but many of the key components are made externally by companies such as Qualcomm and Intel. Apple meanwhile makes their SoC (System on a chip, basically the CPU, wireless receiver etc) in-house, as in by themselves. They have to put the money into R&D, prototyping then mass-production while someone like Qualcomm does that and mass produces many more chips than Apple and can thus lower its cost. Tens of companies buy Qualcomm's many chips but Apple has to make a profit on its own home-designed components and relies solely on people buying the full device to cover all their costs. Note: Devices like the Mac Pro etc do not face this hardware issue as they seem to simply use Intel processors and Vega GPU’s etc. Now onto software! This is the exact same story as hardware as while Samsung can make a phone packed with plenty of hardware features and then pay Google the usage fee for Android; Apple has to innovate and create new versions of iOS and MacOS alongside its new devices which again costs money in R&D. Samsung or Dell etc can simply let Google or Microsoft do all the legwork in the software then either just sell it or whack a skin on it and update your device; the usage fee still hasn't changed. So to conclude this point in a short TL:DR I would simply say that for most other competitors you pay for the hardware of the device, the physical thing in your hand or on your desk while it runs software someone else develops and updates. With an apple device you are also buying the hardware but you also almost buy a licence to use the software apple themselves have developed; you pay for the development of both sides to the device, not just one and a half. Overall I stand by my final point and my first point as the reason Apple products are so expensive but my middle points were more for the “but why do people buy them if they’re so expensive”. So perhaps the real answer is ‘Because people still buy them’? A product, in reality, is only worth what people are willing to pay but as the general consumer base has decided that the hardware and software bundle is worthwhile then who are we to argue?

Many people have already approached this question from the angle that 'overpriced' is an emotional, not a quantitative, measure. If people buy something, it isn't 'overpriced' by definition. I'd like to approach the question from a different perspective: that is, Apple products are not more expensive than non-Apple products. Yes, you can buy a cheap laptop for $300, but all Apple laptops are more expensive than $300. However, when you compare feature to feature, you generally find that Apple isn't more expensive than other products, and in many cases is cheaper. Let's look at the single most astronomically expensive product you can currently buy from Apple: the Mac Pro. As a desktop computer, it has an eyewatering price tag: the baseline system starts at $3,000 and goes up from there. You can get a desktop PC for far less than $3,000. But let's put together an equivalent PC, shall we? The baseline Mac Pro comes with a 4-core Intel Xeon E5 processor, 40GB/s PCIe, 4-channel DDR3 ECC RAM (up to 64 GB supported) clocked at 1866 MHz, PCIe SSD, six Thunderbolt 2 ports, and comes standard even in the bottom-end configuration with two AMD FirePro graphics cards with 2 GB VRAM standard per card (expandable to 6 GB per card). When we start to assemble an equivalent system from another vendor, the price gets really high really fast.  Dell offers a Xeon E5-based workstation for $1,400 if you're a preferred customer (street price is $1,800). But it has slower, non-ECC RAM clocked at 1300 MHz, a serial ATA hard drive rather than an SSD, and only one FirePro graphics card with only 1 GB of VRAM. It is not available with dual FirePros from Dell, and an SSD is not available from Dell--which means going to third-party vendors for those upgrades. Upgrading to a second FirePro will set you back another $650. That alone brings the Dell just over $2,000. An SSD to replace the hard drive adds another $650, so now you're up to $2,700, or $3,000 street. If you want ECC memory you'll have to jump up to the next tier of computers, and it's still only 1600 MHz; as near as I can tell, you can't get 1866 MHz RAM from Dell. Oh, and no Thunderbolt. Adding six ThunderBolt 2 ports adds $916 to the price, for a total of $3,616 preferred buyer, or $3,916 street. And you haven't built an equivalent system: the RAM is slower, and one of the graphics cards only has 1 GB of VRAM. You can do the same calculations with other Macs. The Mac laptop I'm typing this on cost $1,900; it has 16 GB of RAM, separate nVidia graphics, and an Intel Core i7 processor. You can buy a Dell laptop for $269, but it is not an equivalent machine. A dell laptop with the same specs as this system will cost you a minimum of $2,029 on Dell's Web site. So if Apple is "overpriced," so is everyone else!

The simple answer: it depends on your point of view. Apple products are well designed, incorporate, usually cutting edge tecnologies, are innovative and extremely reliable. Apple products also hold their value better than any comparable brand. Why is Apple able to command the premium prices it does when there are other products that, on the surface, have as good or even better specifications? - Apple controls its own ecosystem. It both produces the hardware (yes, I understand that it is not necessarily manufactured in North America but that factor applies to almost all name brands, ie. their claim to be from a particular country is more about design and development than it is about actual manufacture.) and it designs and produces the operating system - one that has a more coherent and substantial base than the majority, if not all, of its competitors. That Apple is in control of both hardware and software is the crucial factor in their success. The only time that their share price took a substantial hit was when they were under the charge of an ext soft-drink CEO who decide that licensing the sortware would be a good idea. It was a disaster. Overnight, clones appeared that had no quality control, were cheaply produced, and simply competed to offer higher and higher specifications without any comprehensive testing or recognition of what the components could reasonably reliably provide. Apple is never-the-less not the company it used to be. Its ethos, in my view, has changed considerably since the death of Steve Jobs. Form a company that was truly concerned with the user experience, it has become a company more focused on remaining at the top of the heap. From a first and foremost computer manufacturer, it has become a manufacturer of consumer desires. I don’t think that this change is good and, in the long term, I see it as being the demise of Apple. Whenever people ask questions like this, I always come back to this quote from Thomas Sowell  "The most fundamental reason why there is no such thing as an objective or “real” value is that there would be no rational basis for economic transactions if there were. When you pay 50 cents for a newspaper, obviously the only reason you do so is that the newspaper is more valuable to you than the 50 cents is. At the same time, the only reason people are willing to sell the newspaper is that 50 cents is more valuable to them than the newspaper is. If there were any such thing as a “real” or objective value of a newspaper—or anything else—neither the buyer nor the seller would benefit from making a transaction at a price equal to that objective value, since what would be acquired would be of no greater value than what was given up. In that case, why bother to make the transaction in the first place?"  Sowell, Thomas (2010-12-28). Basic Economics: A Common Sense Guide to the Economy, 4th Edition (pp. 36-37). Perseus Books Group. Kindle Edition. In short, there is no such thing as "real" value -- so there's no objective definition of "overpriced."  So really the question you should be asking is, "why can Apple get away with charging so much for their products?" I'll give you three reasons: Apple doesn't just make products -- they make emotional connections with people. They don't just lay out specs -- they lay out a central dogma of "thinking different." Sure this all may be marketing mumbo jumbo. But it makes a big difference.Apple controls every aspect of their products down to the very pixel, which means that they can make experiences super consistent. Just compare iOS to Android. Whenever you complain about Android, people say "yeah, well... you just didn't buy the right phone." Very rarely does the iPhone not meet customer expectations -- you usually know what you're getting yourself into when you buy one. And one bad experience can completely ruin the brand for people -- people still complain about blue screens of death in Windows even though they really don't happen anymore. Haven't seen one in over five years!Part of Apple's charm is their exclusivity. If everyone owned Apple products, they would no longer be exclusive. Plus the more marketshare they have, the more viruses and/or anti-trust lawsuits there will be, and the less likely people are to have a consistent experience.
